messages.messageBody:
Yes, I agree: that makes sense.
----- Original Message -----
From: excelsiorilluminati
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, May 02, 2006 6:42 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: theme of tsuba


That seems to be the way the weather is turning. Good call on the
snowflake thing Rich. Gordon the cut-outs being clouds fits for sure
with Jim's snowdrifts and I seem to recall somewhere it being
mentioned for a similar shape. Thanks all, I think you've got it.
John

That seems to be the way the weather is turning. Good call on the
snowflake thing Rich. Gordon the cut-outs being clouds fits for sure
with Jim's snowdrifts and I seem to recall somewhere it being
mentioned for a similar shape. Thanks all, I think you've got it.
John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] theme of tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, The sukashi look like clouds. Gordon
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,

The sukashi look like clouds.

Gordon

On May 3, 2006, at 8:19 AM, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> The brass zogan looks like snow and snowflakes. The usual
> depiction of snowflakes looks more like a sand dollar than an
> actual snow crystal. These do look a little more regular than
> normal, so they might be something else. I don't know what the
> sukashi represents.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> The link will take you to a tsuba. A typical Heianjo tsuba. I think
> the theme is nautical with a sea foam/wrack with rope reaching to
> the
> stars. I have had a comment that they may be snowflakes, but what I
> hope someone can tell me is what the cut-outs represent. They seem
> familiar but I can't recall. Thanks for the help. Pretty quiet
> lately,
> no? John
>
> <http://www.johnstuart.biz/new_page_19.htm>

messages.subject: Re: theme of tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Boy, I never thought of snow drifts and here I am surrounded by 10 ft high drifts. The butterfly thing might work if the opposed cut-out was 180 deg
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Boy, I never thought of snow drifts and here I am surrounded
by 10 ft high drifts. The butterfly thing might work if the opposed
cut-out was 180 deg around but they all orient in a clockwise
fashion. I wish I had that book that deals with themes. John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] theme of tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: A butterfly [cho], perhaps? ... From: Jim Gilbert To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Tuesday, May 02, 2006 4:19 PM Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] theme of
messages.messageBody:
A butterfly [cho], perhaps?
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, May 02, 2006 4:19 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] theme of tsuba


The brass zogan looks like snow and snowflakes. The usual depiction of snowflakes looks more like a sand dollar than an actual snow crystal. These do look a little more regular than normal, so they might be something else. I don't know what the sukashi represents.

Jim



The link will take you to a tsuba. A typical Heianjo tsuba. I think
the theme is nautical with a sea foam/wrack with rope reaching to the
stars. I have had a comment that they may be snowflakes, but what I
hope someone can tell me is what the cut-outs represent. They seem
familiar but I can't recall. Thanks for the help. Pretty quiet lately,
no? John

<http://www.johnstuart.biz/new_page_19.htm>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] theme of tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: The brass zogan looks like snow and snowflakes.  The usual depiction of snowflakes looks more like a sand dollar than an actual snow crystal.  These do look a
messages.messageBody:
The brass zogan looks like snow and snowflakes. The usual depiction of snowflakes looks more like a sand dollar than an actual snow crystal. These do look a little more regular than normal, so they might be something else. I don't know what the sukashi represents.

Jim



The link will take you to a tsuba. A typical Heianjo tsuba. I think
the theme is nautical with a sea foam/wrack with rope reaching to the
stars. I have had a comment that they may be snowflakes, but what I
hope someone can tell me is what the cut-outs represent. They seem
familiar but I can't recall. Thanks for the help. Pretty quiet lately,
no? John

<http://www.johnstuart.biz/new_page_19.htm>

messages.messageBody:
The link will take you to a tsuba. A typical Heianjo tsuba. I think
the theme is nautical with a sea foam/wrack with rope reaching to the
stars. I have had a comment that they may be snowflakes, but what I
hope someone can tell me is what the cut-outs represent. They seem
familiar but I can't recall. Thanks for the help. Pretty quiet lately,
no? John
